_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Pharmacia & Upjohn (P&U), a subsidiary of Pfizer Inc., Portage Road facility Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (API) and Engineering, Maintenance and Utilities (EMU) operations; located in Kalamazoo, Michigan, routinely handles regulated substances in quantities falling under the Risk Management Plan (RMP) reporting requirements of the 1990 amendments to the U.S. Clean Air Act.



The following materials are used in RMP-covered processes at the Kalamazoo API and EMU facilities:



Acetaldehyde

Anhydrous Ammonia

Chlorine

Epichlorohydrin

Ethyl Vinyl Ether

Hydrofluoric acid 70% solution

Hydrogen chloride anhydrous

Hydrogen fluoride anhydrous

Piperidine

Sulfur dioxide

Trimethylchlorosilane

Trimethylamine



The covered materials present in the API operations are in the synthesis of organic chemical compounds used in medicines, or intermediate chemical compounds used in the manufacture of finished pharmaceutical products.  The covered materials present in EMU operations are principally in the chlorination and dechlorination of water used throughout the complex.



While the chances of a worst-case situation actually occurring are incalculable, such a scenario by definition is within the realm of possibility.  That is why P&U's first emergency management priority is accidental release prevention.



Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenarios were modeled using EPA's RMP*Comp or the April 1999 & March 2009 OCA Guidance Document.



To protect the facility's employees, the surrounding community, and the environment; P&U's API and EMU operations adhere to the accident-prevention elements required under the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.  The facility's PSM procedures and policies address all of the required elements of the PSM Standard and RMP Rule Prevention Program 3 elements: Employee Participation, P

rocess Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractors, Pre-Startup Safety Reviews, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permits, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, Compliance Audits and Trade Secrets.



The Kalamazoo Site has implemented an off-site emergency response plan required under the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA) and regularly communicates with the Kalamazoo County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and local emergency-response organizations on matters pertaining to emergency preparedness and chemical storage.  Company representatives have served as members and officers of the LEPC continuously since its inception in the 1980s.  For many, decades, the company has routinely communicated with and shared training experiences with local emergency responders.  In addition, the facility maintains a HazMat Team made up of employees that are on call 24 hours/day and 365 days/year to respond to and mitigate on-site chemical release.



Neither the P&U Kalamazoo API nor the EMU operations have had any accidental release in the past five years involving RMP-covered process that resulted in on-site deaths, injuries, property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Continuous Improvement Initiatives:



In accordance with Pfizer Environment, Health, & Safety (EH&S) Guidelines, the Kalamazoo PGS Site (API, EMU, and Drug Product (DP) operations) has an Environmental Management System.  Regulatory compliance and continuous improvement of the EH&S performance are essential elements in the Environmental Management System.
